Be bright, be bold, be fast!

User centred design is at the heart of DoseBot.
We've spent hours refining the feature set and design based on feedback from our users.

Take a look »

Design Overview

The majority of potential DoseBot users, come from a wide range of backgrounds and mostly from 3rd world and emerging economies. DoseBot offers a service that recognises the different ages, genders and technical know-how of all it’s users. It will provide a service which will not intimidate the less tech literate Generation X-ers but also not bore the more tech savvy digital natives.


Design Goals

Give the user a simple and logical navigation, using visual cues to explain next steps, on their first run-though.

Offer the user easy to use features, which will allow them achieve their goals in just a few simple steps.

Use visual metaphors throughout the product, while acknowledging the various literacy levels of our users.



Create a calm and uncluttered experience for the user and provide a clean UI, embracing white space.

Recognises the nature of a disease like TB and will offer the user a positive experience, primarily through the use of colour.

Use big icons and buttons on screen, allowing users easily work their way through the app, on any size smartphone.

User Profile

We adopted a dual-approach to data gathering, a round of 8 semi-structured interviews with patients, doctors and campaigners, and a structured online survey which had 25 respondents. This gave us a good mix of qualitative and quantitative data.

72%

Female

100%

Own a Smartphone

40%

Between the ages of 25 - 35

13 Months

Average duration of treatment

What They Told Us

Suprise! Our assumptions were incorrect.


The new VDOT method seems to be proving effective and it seems like it could be a good way of monitoring people who can’t always make it to the clinic and cut out high labor costs associated with the DOTs programme.

Dr. Gabriel Fitzpatrick - President of MSF Ireland

The DOTs programme is a cold and clinical treatment process. It’s function is purely to control TB, not to treat and support the patient. The DOTs nurses are so understaffed, which means their time with each patient is limited, so they just get through what they need to but don’t offer any type of care or support, which is so badly needed.

Liz – recovered TB patient

My motivation for sticking to my drug treatment plan, was to finish my Degree and become a Doctor. I would look at the sticky note on the mirror every morning and remind myself why I needed to take my pills.

Zolelwa Sifumba - recovered TB patient

I think we need to move away from DOT policing and "adherence" and rather move towards a platform where patients are encouraged, informed, supported and empowered. It should change their perception of being a victim of TB to a fighter, who has support from their community.

Andrea von Delft – medical doctor and wife of recovered TB patient

Wireframes

Our Initial Designs

Today Screen

The home screen of the app. From here the user can access all the functionality and features of DoseBot. See progress at a glance as well as a daily mood/feeling rating.

Take Medication

Allows users to log their medication intake via video, which is then uploaded to the DoseBot server for review by the user's healthcare professional.

Pill Information

Educates users about the medication they are on, giving them instant access to a reliable source of drug information, including side-effects, precautions and special instructions.


Take Medication - Task Flow Diagram

Hover for zoom


Download »

Storyboard

Isabelle arrives on the ‘Take Medication’ screen (having previously paused a recording)...


Frame 1

She’s presented with an option to resume the previous recording or start a new one. She taps ‘NEW’…

Frame 2

When ready, she taps the record button and a count down lets her know the recording is about to begin.

Frame 3

She begins to take her pills and confirms when each dose has been taken, by ticking boxes.



Frame 4

When she has taken all her morning pills and confirmed each dose with a tick, she presses ‘STOP’.

Frame 5

The system then prompts Isabelle to either SAVE AND UPLOAD or SAVE DRAFT or DELETE recording.

Frame 6

She chooses SAVE AND UPLOAD and once the video is successfully uploaded, she receives confirmation on screen.
